base_note.note_text:
BRONCHOSCOPY NOTE - URGENT
Date: 2025-04-21
Patient: Timothy Clark | MRN: 7063244 | Age: 3 years, Male
Attending: Dr. Patricia Lee, MD (Pediatric IP)
Location: Children's Hospital of Philadelphia

INDICATION: 3-year-old male with witnessed aspiration of peanut 2 hours ago. Stridor, decreased breath sounds on right.

PROCEDURE: Rigid bronchoscopy with foreign body removal

ANESTHESIA: General anesthesia (sevoflurane induction, propofol maintenance)

FINDINGS:
- Vocal cords: Edematous
- Trachea: Mucosal inflammation
- Right mainstem: Peanut fragment lodged at RMS/BI junction causing complete obstruction
- Left lung: Normal

PROCEDURE: Using 3.5mm pediatric rigid bronchoscope, the peanut was visualized. Optical forceps used to grasp and remove the foreign body en bloc. Post-removal inspection showed mucosal edema and erythema but patent airway. Second fragment found in RLL, also removed.

SPECIMENS: Peanut fragments x 2 (gross specimen)

COMPLICATIONS: None

POST-PROCEDURE: Dexamethasone 0.5mg/kg IV given. Patient extubated, stridor resolved. Admission for overnight observation and racemic epinephrine PRN.

Dr. Patricia Lee, MD

code_rationales.31635: Rigid bronchoscopy with foreign body removal - pediatric peanut aspiration.

coding_review.overall_assessment: FB removal successful via rigid bronchoscopy.

cpt_codes.description: Bronchoscopy; with removal of foreign body

variations.note_text:
INTERVENTIONAL PULMONOLOGY PROCEDURE DOCUMENTATION
============================================================

PATIENT IDENTIFICATION AND DEMOGRAPHICS
----------------------------------------
Patient: Austin Long
Medical Record Number: 6481566
Date of Birth: N/A
Age at Procedure: 18 years
Procedure Date: 2024-03-12

CLINICAL INDICATION AND PREOPERATIVE ASSESSMENT
----------------------------------------
The patient presented with airway foreign body - peanut aspiration. Following comprehensive multidisciplinary evaluation and informed consent discussion detailing procedural risks, benefits, and alternatives, the patient elected to proceed with the proposed intervention.

PROCEDURAL METHODOLOGY AND TECHNIQUE
----------------------------------------

Foreign Body Removal:


INTRAPROCEDURAL FINDINGS
----------------------------------------
- Vocal cords: Edematous
- Trachea: Mucosal inflammation
- Right mainstem: Peanut fragment lodged at RMS/BI junction causing complete obstruction
- Left lung: Normal


POSTPROCEDURAL ASSESSMENT AND DISPOSITION
----------------------------------------
The procedure was completed without immediate complications. The patient demonstrated hemodynamic stability throughout and was transferred to the recovery area in satisfactory condition.

PROCEDURAL CODING DOCUMENTATION
----------------------------------------
Current Procedural Terminology Codes: 31635

This documentation has been prepared in accordance with institutional standards for procedural documentation and coding compliance.

variations.note_text:
PROCEDURE NOTE

Date: 2024-11-15
Patient: Andrew Scott
MRN: 2582498
Age/Sex: 18yo M

Attending Physician: [Attending]
Resident/Fellow: [Trainee, PGY-X]

INDICATION:
Airway foreign body - peanut aspiration

CONSENT:
Informed consent obtained. Risks, benefits, and alternatives discussed.
Patient verbalized understanding and agreed to proceed.

TIMEOUT:
Performed. Correct patient, procedure, and site confirmed.

SEDATION:
General

PROCEDURE STEPS:
1. Patient positioned and monitored
2. Sedation administered per protocol
3. Topical anesthesia applied to airway
4. Foreign Body Removal performed
5. Scope withdrawn
6. Patient recovered without complication

SPECIMENS:
Peanut fragments x 2 (gross specimen)

COMPLICATIONS:
None

EBL:
Minimal

DISPOSITION:
To recovery, stable condition

CPT CODES: 31635

ATTESTATION:
I was present for the entire procedure and agree with the above documentation.
[Attending Signature]

variations.note_text:
On 2025-03-16, Donald Jones, a 18-year-old male (MRN 3767803), underwent bronchoscopic evaluation for Airway foreign body - peanut aspiration. The patient received General and the procedure was performed in standard fashion. The procedure included foreign body removal. 

On examination, the airways were systematically inspected. The visualized airways appeared patent without significant abnormality. The procedure was completed without immediate complications. 

The patient tolerated the procedure well and was transferred to the recovery area in stable condition. Specimens obtained were sent for appropriate analysis and results will be reviewed at follow-up. The preliminary assessment is foreign body aspiration. 

Procedural coding: 31635.
